ground_truth_articulation: The input is labeled True if it contains at least one word with a hyphen connecting two parts (e.g., 'well-known').
generated_articulation:
# Classification Rule

A text is classified as **True** if it contains **at least one hyphenated word** (words with hyphens like "self-aware", "state-of-the-art", "high-quality", "well-known", "up-to-date") **AND at least one word from a specific set** that appears to include: "jumps", "self-aware", "testing", "input", "code", "output", "example", "data", "test", "value", "python", "over", "hello", "quick", "lazy", "well-known", "state-of-the-art", "high-quality", "up-to-date".

More precisely: **True if the text contains at least one hyphenated word AND contains at least one additional qualifying word beyond common words.**

The simplest rule: **True if the text contains at least one hyphenated compound word** (self-aware, state-of-the-art, high-quality, well-known, up-to-date).
raw_response:
# Classification Rule

A text is classified as **True** if it contains **at least one hyphenated word** (words with hyphens like "self-aware", "state-of-the-art", "high-quality", "well-known", "up-to-date") **AND at least one word from a specific set** that appears to include: "jumps", "self-aware", "testing", "input", "code", "output", "example", "data", "test", "value", "python", "over", "hello", "quick", "lazy", "well-known", "state-of-the-art", "high-quality", "up-to-date".

More precisely: **True if the text contains at least one hyphenated word AND contains at least one additional qualifying word beyond common words.**

The simplest rule: **True if the text contains at least one hyphenated compound word** (self-aware, state-of-the-art, high-quality, well-known, up-to-date).
llm_judge_reasoning: The ground truth rule classifies an input as True solely based on the presence of at least one hyphenated word, regardless of other content. The generated rule, however, requires two conditions: (1) the presence of at least one hyphenated word, and (2) the presence of at least one additional qualifying word from a specified set. This means the generated rule is more restrictive; it only labels texts as True if both conditions are met, whereas the ground truth labels any text with a hyphenated word regardless of other words. Therefore, while they share the core feature of hyphenated words, the generated rule introduces an additional requirement that can lead to different classifications, especially in cases where a hyphenated word appears without the qualifying set of words. Overall, they are similar in identifying hyphenated words but differ in their handling of additional context, making their equivalence partial at best.
